title: How To Deal With A Partner Who's Always On Social Media
summary: Dating apps are designed to make us feel like our love lives are always just a couple of swipes away. With so many options, it can be hard to decide who to message next, or to figure out what’s appropriate to say. Your partner might not like being reminded that all of these other people are out there, waiting to meet them. Set aside time to be with each other, even if you’re living together. Don’t let your partner use dating apps as a way to treat others poorly.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`According to recent analysis by Statista, the average millennial spends almost one hour every day on social media. That\u2019s not just posting pictures and updating our profiles, but also lurking on other people\u2019s profiles. The rise of dating apps like Tinder, Bumble, and Happn has only hastened this tendency. In fact, an article in Fast Company suggests that millennials are so preoccupied with online dating that they now spend more time on it than on any other leisure activity besides watching TV or listening to music.
On top of all this, many couples now meet their partners online \u2013 a third of marriages in the U.S. start with either partner meeting their future spouse through an online dating site or app. While it\u2019s easy to feel pressured into signing up for these services if you don\u2019t have friends who are single and looking for love, being in a relationship with someone who does use them regularly can be challenging at times.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"What\u2019s so frustrating about dating apps?"),mdx("p",null,"Dating apps are designed to make us feel like our love lives are always just a couple of swipes away. They remind us that we could be meeting someone new at any moment, whenever we have a couple of minutes to spare. With so many options, it can be hard to decide who to message next, or to figure out what\u2019s appropriate to say. Plus, the abundance of choices can be a source of anxiety. After all, how do you know which people you should spend your time pursuing, and which ones you should let go?"),mdx("p",null,"Of course, the problem is that you might want to spend some time browsing dating apps, but your partner might not like being reminded that all of these other people are out there, waiting to meet them."),mdx("h2",null,"The problem with living together and using dating apps."),mdx("p",null,"Even if your partner is single and looking for a relationship, they may have bad experiences on dating apps. Because it\u2019s easy to be rude and inconsiderate when you\u2019re behind a screen, many people use dating apps as a way to treat others poorly. It can be especially hard to deal with if your partner decides to start dating multiple people at once, and they use these apps to do so."),mdx("p",null,"Even if your partner is respectful and honest when they\u2019re using dating apps, there are still reasons why you might not enjoy hearing about their experiences. You probably don\u2019t want to know about their dates, or hear about the people they meet. You might want to avoid dating apps for that reason alone."),mdx("h2",null,"How to navigate these challenges (and feel better about it)."),mdx("p",null,"When you\u2019re living with your partner, it\u2019s important to remember that you two are in a relationship, too. You might be together all day, every day, but that doesn\u2019t mean that you can\u2019t also have some alone time. It\u2019s important to set aside time to be with each other, even if you\u2019re living together."),mdx("p",null,"When you\u2019re living with your partner, it\u2019s easy to be constantly connected. You might be in the same room, but still feel like you\u2019re never actually connecting. That might be because you\u2019re both only focused on your screens, not each other. So set some time aside each day to be with each other. You\u2019ll have time to talk later. It might be helpful to put your phones away during this time."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Let It Become A Battle"),mdx("p",null,"If your partner is spending a lot of time on dating apps, it\u2019s easy to get resentful. You might feel like they\u2019re putting themselves first and living their lives for themselves. While it\u2019s important to be able to spend some time focusing on yourself, there are ways to do that that don\u2019t involve dating apps."),mdx("p",null,"So, sit down together and talk about how each of you spend your time, and what you each want from it. Then, work out some ground rules. For example, you might decide that your partner can spend as much time on dating apps as they want as long as they don\u2019t meet anyone in person until they\u2019ve dated you for six months."),mdx("h2",null,"Find The Bright Side Of Their Socially Mediated Life"),mdx("p",null,"You might not want your partner to spend all their time online, but they might have reasons for doing so. Maybe they have anxiety and dating apps give them the freedom to explore meeting new people in a low-pressure environment. Maybe they just really like talking to people online and prefer it to talking in person."),mdx("p",null,"Instead of resenting their online habits, try to understand them and why they do what they do. This might be especially helpful if you\u2019re living with your partner and want to avoid spending too much time on dating apps yourself."),mdx("h2",null,"Take Care Of Yourself, Too!"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s important to remember that dating apps are not the be all and end all of relationships. Yes, people can and do meet their life partners through dating apps. But they can also meet them at work, at school, through friends, etc. Your partner spending time on dating apps does not mean that you\u2019re less likely to meet someone."),mdx("p",null,"On the other hand, you still need to take care of yourself. This can be especially important if your partner is dating multiple people at once. It can be easy to feel like you\u2019re being neglected or pushed aside. Make sure to have time for yourself, and to spend time with friends and family."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Beat the Winter Blues

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The winter blues is a mood disorder that can affect anyone, not just people from northern regions. Symptoms of the winter blues are essentially SAD (seasonal affective disorder) brought on by the shorter days and colder temperatures of winter. If you find yourself feeling blue during the colder months but don\u2019t necessarily have a reason to be, you might have the winter blues. The good news is that you can combat this feeling with a little help from your friends and some lifestyle changes.
Whether you have or have had the winter blues in the past, there are ways to boost your spirits when those long, dreary days of January creep up on you like an old friend you don\u2019t want to see again. Here are some ways to beat those pesky winter blues and get back to your happy self!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Reduce Stress during the Holiday Season
50 Ways to Keep the Spark Alive in Your Relationship
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Tips for Eating Healthy on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you trying to eat healthier but find that healthy foods are expensive? Are you trying to make a good meal last for several days and not just one? Are you struggling to find affordable, healthy options near your home or work? If so, you\u2019re not alone. Eating healthy can be expensive and challenging. The cost of healthy food has gone up while the cost of unhealthy food has gone down. But this doesn\u2019t mean that eating healthy is impossible; it just means we all need to get a little bit more creative.
Eating well on a budget can be challenging, but it isn\u2019t impossible. Making smart choices about what you buy as well as how you cook your food can make a big difference in how much money you spend on food each month and how healthy your diet is at the same time.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Their Phone

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Now and again, your significant other will probably spend more time with their phone than with you. After all, it\u2019s 2018, and smartphones are practically a necessity for anyone who wants to stay connected. But if your partner is glued to their cell 24/7, it can obviously become a source of tension between you two. It\u2019s natural to feel a little jealous when someone you care about spends more time texting than talking with you, after all. And this is especially true if they seem to be ignoring you while they do so.
If your partner always seems to be on their phone, there could be several explanations \u2014 from an online affair to simply being an avid social media user. Regardless of the reasons why your partner might spend so much time on their phone, though, the way that you react definitely matters. Being insecure and accusatory about something as innocent as checking messages isn\u2019t likely to lead anywhere positive, after all. Here are some tips for dealing with a partner who\u2019s always on their phone:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: From First Date to Soulmate: How to Know If You're on the Right Track

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`There are so many first date horror stories out there \u2014 awkward silences, strange amateur- magician tricks, and cringe-worthy pick-up lines being just a few of them. But getting past these awkward initial stages and finding a potential partner who you can connect with on a deeper level is no mean feat. Figuring out if someone is your soulmate or simply the first step to becoming one isn\u2019t easy. Even though it can feel like we\u2019re constantly being bombarded with images of fairy tale love and meet-cute romances, dating in real life isn\u2019t always so straightforward. Unless you\u2019re living under a rock, you probably know that letting somebody into your private world isn\u2019t something to take lightly.
But how do you know if you\u2019re on the right track when it comes to dating? Whether you\u2019ve just met someone new and want to get to know them better without rushing things or have been seeing somebody for some time and are wondering if they could be The One, here are some signs that could indicate that this person may be more than just a casual partner\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Get through a Break-Up

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Everyone knows break-ups are tough. Even if you know the relationship is ending, the final moments can still be filled with pain and heartbreak. However, a breakup doesn\u2019t need to be final in every sense of the word. In time, you will recover from your failed relationship and move on with your life. Here are some effective ways to make this happen sooner rather than later.
If you\u2019ve recently broken up with your partner or dating partner, it can feel like the end of the world. But it\u2019s not! A relationship coming to an end does not mean there is something wrong with you or that you aren\u2019t good enough for anyone or that you will never find love again. Your heart is broken at this moment because you cared deeply about this person - now you just have to understand why and how things went south so that it doesn\u2019t happen again in your future relationships`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Start Living a More Eco-Friendly Lifestyle

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Did you know that a single person produces about 1.6 tons of CO2 per year? Did you also know that producing one cotton t-shirt uses almost 19 gallons of water and produces 3.5lbs of CO2?"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Make Your Mornings Easier

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`You know those people who seem to get out of bed with ease every morning? You know, the people that you see on Instagram and wonder how they\u2019re so happy so early in the day? Well, we hate to break it to you but those people have their own set of problems. Getting up after a long night is hard for them too; the only difference is that their solutions work.
These people have their own rituals and habits when it comes to waking up in the morning. If these folks can do it then why can\u2019t we? It\u2019s because some of us are too comfortable, which means we need to shake things up! Do you want to be one of those people who gets out of bed with ease and has a productive day ahead of them? In this blog post, we\u2019ll tell you 5 ways you can make your mornings easier.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
